And thus we reach the inevitable third instalment of one of the greatest trilogies ever made. Third instalments have a strange legacy. Barring a precious few, the third in a series is often the weakest link. Alien, Spiderman, even the Godfather, these series have a great original, an equally amazing sequel and then an underwhelming threequel. Yes, that's a word. And after the mighty previous two in The Lord of the Rings trilogy, no one could have blamed cinemagoers for expecting the worst when buying their tickets for The Return of the King. But it takes all of 30 seconds to realise that tradition does not apply here. 

After embarking on his mission in the first film, Frodo is now closer than ever to his goal of destroying the One Ring in Mordor. His companion/life partner Sam and their guide Gollum are endeavouring to help him get there but Sam's suspicion of Gollum continues to grow. Gandalf takes Pippin to Gondor with a message for the steward and Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli ride with Theoden to join forces with Gondor to fight Sauron's armies. 

By now the characters are well worn grooves for their actors and each of them fit into them perfectly. Even Elijah Wood whose character, despite being the principal, has the least to do dramatically, manages to maintain a fantastically restrained performance which, whilst lacklustre for the most part, fits his character to a tee. Other have more to do such as Viggo Mortensen whose character is struggling with the notion of becoming king and Sean Astin whose friend likes his new friend better than him. Despite initial disappointment about the double-act of Merry and Pippin being broken up, the separate journeys they each take allow their characters to find a new steel and reach new depths of emotion. The other double-act of the series is still alive and well, however, as Legolas and Gimli try to out-do each other in battle, drinking and general shenanigans. Ian McKellen stands out as always, showing that Gandalf may not have everything under control for the first time since Moria. All around the cast perform admirably, giving their all in every circumstance which adds to the immersive experience created by their director. 

Fans may have been worried that there was nowhere else for Peter Jackson to go. After covering the exquisite cinematography side in Fellowship and the sweeping epic side in Towers, what else was there to do? A lot, it seems, as Jackson pulls out all the stops to create an epic film which focusses as much on the intricacies of battle as it does on the grandeur of the surrounds. Every shot counts and every moment matters under Jackson's keen eye, whether its a slow motion montage or a terrifyingly tense encounter with a giant spider, Peter Jackson seems to have an instinctive feel for Tolkien's work in terms of mood and tone. He blends comedy with tragedy and tension with sentiment with a deft touch which makes you think that he wrote the thing himself. 

Howard Shore once again brings the thunder as he continues and expands his incredible score. It's hard to imagine the Battle of Pelennor Fields without his amazing soundtrack backing it up. In fact, some moments, such as Faramir's ill-fated attack, rest completely on the emotional stirrings of Mr. Shore and he comes through in spades. 

The screenplay is just as versatile as ever, weaving deftly between sentiment and comedy without becoming stagnant or unnecessary. The restraint of the screenplays has been a trademark of the entire series, resisting the urge to spell everything out for the audience, rather letting them figure it out for themselves. It steers well clear of becoming overly preachy as well, as a film with this sort of content can become as well as staying away from an overdose of fantastical phrases which could turn away the less fantasy inclined viewers. 

It's impossible to write this review without mentioning the source material. Tolkien's epic tale was written nearly fifty years ago yet it is still able to captivate readers to this very day. Adults and children alike have been captivated by its fantasy world and the mythology behind it and, most importantly, without it we would never have these amazing films.

Review In A Nutshell:

One hell of a film! The Lord of the Rings has concluded with The Return of the King, an epic scaled film filled with battles and drama that many franchises fail to deliver. I want to simply get this out of the way before moving on to this review, The Return of the King is not a better crafted film than The Fellowship of the Ring; it may display its elements at a much grander scale, it does not carry the same power that the initial film was able to deliver. Despite from what I have just said, this is a majestic film that leaves audiences a feeling of both physical and emotional satisfaction.

The Return of the King follows the events of The Two Towers; Isengard has fallen, Rohan and Helm's Deep was defended, and the two hobbits (Frodo and Sam) have reached closer to the land of Mordor where they will destroy the ring. The previous film handled three storylines in such an unsatisfying and distracting way, constant cutting back and forth between each story too frequently, but The Return of the King manages to tell its multiple stories with improved precision, letting each one linger enough for the audience to completely engage themselves in and transition at the perfect emotional point. It was because of this that I was able to care so much more for the characters, the new set of characters that appeared in the previous film have now grown on me and created a sense of weight on me, which I feel whenever they are endangered during battle. For a long and expansive film, it manages to not let itself feel complicated to sit through, challenging audiences through emotions rather than intellectually (which is not really necessary for a film of this type) through immense character development and previously established themes. The film brings the audience back to the level depth that was found in the first film, reaching out for the internal troubles that carry with Frodo; how the Ring has continuously and gradually affected him, which would all come together by the end, where the film shows the emotional and psychological aftermath of his personal journey.

The battle scenes in this film are gloriously large and abundant, featuring top notch special and practical effects that lets audiences be drawn into its world; escaping our troubled reality for another that is equally fantastical and emotionally moving. The defence of Gondor was the best out of all the battles in the film, it shows Jackson at his most peak when it comes to handling visual effects, showing just how ambitious, dedicated and talented he is as a filmmaker. His influences of epic filmmaking is certainly in full display here, taking homage to them without coming off as a thief; obvious examples of these homages are George Lucas' Empire Strikes Back and Mel Gibson's Braveheart. Similar to Lucas' Return of the Jedi, Return of the King is an epic film; it isn't the thrill and warm action-drama blend of the first film, and it is not the dark and story building mixture of the second film; this is a film that is all about the much larger picture, the climax that we have all been waiting for, ensuring that even the smallest of scenes would remain with the epic atmosphere that is demanded.

The film's score, composed by Howard Shore, reaches beyond of what is expected; it creates a sense of excitement that never at all feels overbearing, and it creates emotional impact that never feels manipulative. It has the power to keep our skin activated with goose bumps for an extended period of time, primarily held by the grandness of the score. It keeps our mind and body constantly locked to what is shown on screen, regardless if what is being shown is uneventful. During the end of the film, we find a scene where Aragorn has been titled as King and he approaches the hobbits in the crowd; the hobbits initially bow to him, but instead he tells them "You bow to one", then he bows along with everyone behind him to the four hobbits. The scene alone can choke one up, but the addition of Shore's score, it conjured up tears in my eyes, simply waiting to fall; one of the rare instances where I display this sort of emotion.

The performance from its cast is wonderful as expected, particularly during its ending, where the characters are acting with subtlety, forcing to use their emotional range as a performer rather than their physicality. I do not need to dwell into the performances, because honestly it is just as great as the previous two films and to break it down here in this review would be futile.

The Return of the King is a satisfying conclusion to an amazing trilogy. It has surpassed anything its audiences, even the hardcore fans of the novels, have ever expected. The trilogy's influence can be felt in almost all of the films that have followed it and for a film to have that power is deserving of a high spot in the history of cinema's greatest triumphs!

After two break taking installments, 2003 was the year when Frodo´s journey to destroy the Ring got to an end thus supposedly ending Middle Earth´s story. "The Return of the King" become the most profitable installment of the trilogy and also earned 11 Oscars, tying "Titanic" and "Ben-Hur" for the most earned Oscars, including Best Film. Is "Return of the King" the best installment of the series? 
After the end of "The Two Towers", the majority of the Fellowship reunites until Gandalf learns that Sauron is planning to unleash his Orc army in Minas Tirith, capital of Gondor, thus beginning the final battle for Middle-Earth´s fate. Meanwhile, Frodo, Sam and Gollum are on the final segments of their journey to Mordor but Gollum's intentions may no longer be to help his master fulfill his quest. 
By the end of "The Two Towers", audiences expectations were higher than ever  for a epic and worthy finale to this beloved and long story and thankfully, this final chapter succeeded in that aspect. By this point, it's redundant to mention all the greatness that Jackson archived with this trilogy (you can read about them in my reviews of the last installments) but still "The Return of the King" has some new elements worth to be mention: It counts with numerous well made battle sequences, some characters managed to still count with some character development and Jackson used the 3hr runtime wisely (excluding that 20 minute Epilogue) thus my problem with the pacing goes away mainly because the film is either focused on gigantic battle sequences or the intriguing relationship between Frodo, Sam and Gollum. Even if "Return of the King" gets a lot of things right and is an epic ending to this beloved trilogy, I believe that in comparison this is the weakest film of the trilogy mainly because of two reasons: 1) Excluding the Frodo, Sam and Gollum storyline, this film had almost no story, "The Two Towers" pretty much ended the rest of the story in a clever way and now the rest of the Fellowship is in the middle of numerous battles which are a distraction for both Sauron and the audience at times. 2)  After the third act is over, at about the 3 hr mark, this film gives us 20 minutes of Epilogue with the now famous "8 endings" when they are not necessary at all other than providing some fan service to lovers of the source material. I know that people had ton of emotion when they saw those endings but for a movie they really drag and I believed that if Jackson had ended this film at the 3 hr mark it would have make "The Return of the King" an even better film, I know that every single fan of the source material will disagree with me because they want to see those happy moments after battling for the fate of Middle-Earth but that's my opinion as a non Tolkien fan. 
"The Return of the King" is a fantastic ending to a fantastic story but unfortunately drags a little with that last 20 minutes. If you are a diehard lover of Tolkien´s work you will adore this final chapter no matter what. One of the best third/final installments of all time and one of the best fantasy films ever made.
A perfect end to the trilogy, with so much emotion and action.

The saga ends with a final battle of Middle-Earth as all else depends on Frodo's effort in destroying the Ring. Jackson's last chapter of the epic journey ends in the most grandeur, epic way as possible as the tale progresses with proper pacing albeit various character developments. The cinematography is as charming as its predecessor, which segregated parts of the story taking place at a few different place of Middle-Earth are systematically broken down into chronologically inter-related events. While the setting of the Middle-Earth gets abruptly darker as Frodo and Sam set foot into the evil realm of Mordor, hope still prevails across the land of Men as Gondor and Rohan join forces to fight one last battle with the Orcs. In conclusion, the third part of the story relishes on the courage of Men and celebrates the ever resilient spirit of perseverance and bravery while facing tough times.

The final chapter to the Lord of the Rings Trilogy, The Return of the King is a complete triumph. The film is a remarkable work of art in both storytelling and visuals. Peter Jackson brings a close to an incredible set of films and characters, and he does it with such grand action and emotional weight that makes the film like this a true classic. Inspiring and breathtaking to the end,the epic final battle leads our characters into mortal danger and offers us one of the best movies ever crafted.Not just a fantasy epic or a great movie,but a masterpiece.

With the forces of Isengard defeated, Aragorn (Viggo Mortensen) and the armies of Rohan and Gondor prepare to face Sauron for the fate of Middle-Earth. Meanwhile as Frodo (Elijah Wood) and Sam (Sean Astin) move closer and closer towards Mordor, Gollum (Andy Serkis) now fully consumed by his evil side, plots to lead the two Hobbits into a fatal trap...

Although the last two films had their fair share of cool setpieces, a majority of scenes in those films were used for the worldbuilding of Middle-Earth and to establish characters.

With the final film however, Peter Jackson goes all out in filming some of the best battle sequences ever put to film, with the infamous Battle of the Pelennor Fields being a marvel in terms of spectacle and cinematography.

Although the butt-numbing running time of over four hours can be tiring for some, it's thankfully not boring as time is used to wrap up every character's arc beautifully. Frodo, Sam, Aragorn, Gandalf (Ian McKellen), Gollum and the rest of the cast are characters that the audience has grown to love, so in spite of the criticism of the numourous endings, they are essential in giving each of them the send-off they deserve.

Overall, with all these things said about it, The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King is a triumphant conclusion to the epic story of The Ring and being the first fantasy film to win the Oscar for Best Picture, a crowning victory for fans of the much underappreciated genre. "The Road goes ever on" indeed...

As I was watching a NBA Playoffs game with my dad the other night, a commercial for the Warcraft movie came on. He asked me "Why is your generation so obsessed with the fantasy movie genre?" This is why. Return of the King is my personal favorite of the LOTR franchise. It has the same strengths as its predecessors - powerful film score, solid performances across the board from an ensemble cast, and incredible visual effects that still hold up to this day. What sets this movie apart from the others is the finality of it all. Yes, there are 3 or 4 end scenes in the last 20 minutes, but I look at that as a celebration of the accomplishments of this series. Not only is this movie solid from beginning to end, but it has some of my favorite moments in cinema history (SPOILER WARNING): the shot of Aragorn leading the undead army into battle, Faramir's troops charging into battle with Pippen singing in the background, and, of course, "You bow to no one." "FRODO AND MOUNT DOOM"

- The epic conclusion of the famous 'the Lord of the Rings' trilogy by director Peter Jackson (King Kong, the Hobbit) and based upon the novels of J.R.R. Tolkien is this 2003 'the Lord of the Rings: the Return of the King'. The film is tied for largest numbers of Academy Awards with Ben-Hur (1959) and Titanic (1997). The story continues where part two had ended. Jackson is able to bring the whole fantasy world of Tolkien to life. Great story, amazing cast and stunning special effects leading to an epic ending make this movie a true must-see film. Starring Elijah Wood (The Faculty), Ian McKellen (X-men Trilogy), Viggo Mortensen (A History of Violence), Sean Astin (The Goonies), Orlando Bloom (Pirates of the Caribbean) , John-Rhys Davies (Indiana Jones films), Hugo Weaving (The Matrix), Cate Blanchett (The Aviator), Ian Holm (Alien), Liv Tyler (Armageddon) and Andy Serkins (King Kong) as Gollum.

Gandalf (McKellen), Aragorn (Mortensen), Gimli (Davies), Legolas (Bloom) and the knights of King Théoden reunite with the Halflings Merry and Peppin who were able to destroy the Orc encampment at Isengard with the help from the Ents and imprison the wizard Saruman in his tower. Now the heroes must plan to defend the legendary fortress Minas Tirith against the army of Sauron. Aragorn, Gimli and Legolas must go to the Undying Lands to make an alliance with the dead.

In the meantime, Frodo Baggins (Wood) and his friend Samwise (Astin) are travelling through the dangerous land of Mordor in order to find Mount Doom where they can destroy the Ring. They are guided there by Gollum (Serkins), who leads them to the lair of the giant spider Shelob. Because he wants his precious ring back...

Generally speaking I don't like the LOTR series.  I acknowledge they look great but for me I hate them because I was continually let down throughout them.  Far too often in the LOTR series I think the story builds up these great idea's or characters and them lets me down whenever something big is supposed to happen.
For example: The Ring Wraiths.  Great name...great design..great backstory and they do a good job of showing how afraid of them everyone was.

oh...let me put it out there that I never read the books and I think any discussion of the books is irrelevant since I'm watching a movie and that's what I'll judge it by. Back to the wraiths..

I LOVED these guys and couldn't wait to seem them flex their muscle (or bone).  In the first movie, a big wave in the river washed them away.  In retrospect it wasn't even all that impressive.  I'll call that a flawed execution of the idea (water will get rid of them).  There was a scene where they came upon the hobbit in a derelict tower and I don't remember anything cool about (I need to rewatch these films I agree..it's just I've never been interested enough to spend that much time again).  ANd finally at the end of the film during the big battle scene it looks like we're going to get to see them do something really cool and what happens? He gets killed before he ever does anything cool. 

Gandalf?  HAH!  I love the idea of the most powerful wizard and he certainly looks the part but aside from one scene where he was swinging his stick what giant magical things did he do?!  He made his staff into a giant flashlight.  That's it! I waited hours upon hours to see him make a big flahslight?!  Huge let down!   Yes the Balrog was cool and he has a great line in the scene but we don't get to really see what makes him so magical.  

I've got more but I'm sure no one will read this.

I want to add that I am shocked by how much I absolutely love the 2 new Hobbit movies (Hobbit and Desolation of Smaug).  Hell..I give those films 5 stars.  Love them and I can easily say that I think Desolation of Smaug is the best of all these films.

Favorite film of all time, even beating out the Godfather Parts 1 & 2. Everything about it is pulchritudinous and the story is phenomenal. The dilemmas the story brings about seems archetypal but hey, it's in the world of Middle Earth. The characters, especially Aragorn, Gollum and even Sam, were perfect. The complexities that lie within them were portrayed... perfectly (sounds redundant right?). The bounds of friendship, duty and what it means to live upon a world you care for were explored beautifully in this film. Even though I preach peace instead of war, the war scenes in this film is just jaw dropping and amazing. I wanted to be part of it and reminded me it's worth it to fight for the world you love. On other terms, a lot of people say the film is too long with an ending that seems to be relentless. You have to look at the films as whole and see it as a celebrated achievement and how everything comes down to. It's a film that come to full circle as the story finally ends. The Lesnie's cinematography and Howard Shore's music sweep you away into this fantastic place and hell, it did it's job. Even the side stories along with the two main story arcs were integrated well and even packed a punch.

I have to go more in depth with the characters and story because this film deserves its merit and praise. Peter Jackson did an amazing job making these numerous characters valid and memorable characters. Each one of them has depth and contribute to film in a dynamic manner. The character of Aragorn stole the show in my perspective. Viggo Mortensen sold that role of the mix of a Jesus figure, prodigal son/ King Arthur vibe. He was damaged and he came back to the throne, not for the power. He came with the intention to unite men again a danger that would threaten their way of life and the world they love. Even the characters that were dicks were memorable. I love Bernard Hill's Theoden. He was one that redeemed himself when it counted. His speech was memorable and the way it was filmed and captured in the screen was purely breathtaking. I love how the story tackles every aspect of life without feeling like it was being shoved in our faces. Of course some stories are more valid than others but it should be that way. But, it gave enough to us to where it satisfies to that perfect degree. It's the perfect overall film, that encompasses everything.

The only gripe I had about the film but was resolved in the extended edition was a few scenes that were left out in the theatrical release. The first one was Saruman's demise. That scene flowed well with the narrative and I'm pretty sure the audience would have been okay to see the Saruman issue resolve the way it should have been. The way he die was symbolic and fulfilling. The theatrical has him locked in his tower forever but the big gap of that is how in the hell would the Palantir be in the water if Saruman is locked in the tower. Another one was that Peter Jackson chose to omit the scene with the mouth of Sauron. The scene had the emotional weight and gave Aragorn and the men of the West (with one elf, dwarf, wizard and two hobbits) more of a reason to take on the army. It justifies them going all out taking out as many of Sauron's forces. I understand why Jackson kept it out so it is simpler to have them buy more time for Frodo but the gap is that Aragorn and Gandalf do not know that. It would've made sense seeing the mouth of Sauron bring the armor of Frodo out and say the hobbit is dead. Either than that, everything is perfect.

Peter Jackson created not just a film, but a grand art in itself. I can't think of any film that did what the Return of the King did in its standard. Looking back upon Citizen Kane, Ben- Hur and like I said the Godfather, it did everything better and set upon a new standard for film for generations to come.

It's very rare when a third chapter, especially the finale chapter of a film franchise, raises my spirits up. Previously, my favorite final chapter film was Return of the Jedi, but with JJ Abrams and Disney working on a new trilogy, Return of the Jedi is not the last film anymore. Now my favorite final chapter is the final chapter in the LOTR trilogy, The Return of the King, a finale that truly raises the bar in creating epic adventure movies.

As Frodo (Elijah Wood), Sam (Sean Astin), and Gollum (Andy Serkis) are closer and closer to Mordor to destroy the One Ring, the Ring begins to take a heavy toll on Frodo, making it really difficult for Frodo to trust his companions, especially Sam, who's still suspicious of Gollum's part in the journey. Also in Middle-earth, the Battle for Middle-earth begins, and Aragorn (Viggo Mortenson), with an extremely outnumbered army, leads the ultimate battle to defeat Saruron's armies and reclaim the throne of Gondor.

Also appearing in this great film is Ian McKellen as Gandalf, Dominic Monaghan and Billy Boyd as Merry and Pippin, Orlando Bloom as Legolas, John Rhys-Davies as Gimli, Bernard Hill as King Théoden, Hugo Weaving as Elrond, Liv Tyler as Arwen, Cate Blanchett as Galadriel, Miranda Otto as Eowyn, Karl Urban as Eomer, David Wenham as Faramir, Ian Holm in a small role as Bilbo, and John Noble as Denethor, Boromir/Faramir's father and the Steward of Gondor.

You'd think that with a franchise like LOTR, something this bog would fizzle out after the first installment. But Peter Jackson, an extremely dedicated director who's the most obsessed fan of Tolkien's source material that I've heard of, creates the ultimate finale, creating, according to film critic Peter Travers, "a film epic in which all future epics will be judged." I strongly believe that there hasn't been an epic this epic since William Wyler stunned us with that glorius chariot race in Ben-Hur and David Lean's excellent cinematography-filled wonder in Lawrence of Arabia. 

I've said it before, and I'll say it again; Middle-earth is one of the most fantastic worlds ever created in film history. With the new Hobbit trilogy already confirming this fact, it's safe to say that the stunning New Zealand locations will be hard to top when creating incredible and fantastic worlds in cinema. From the stunning cinematic shots of the green grass to the dark and murky world of Mordor, Middle-earth has never been the same. The best cinematography in the whole trilogy; nuff said.

While my favorite battle sequence in the trilogy is Helm's Deep in The Two Towers, the action sequences here are still mind blowing, with the huge standout being the Battle of Minis Tirith and the Pellinor Fields. The sequence is at least 30 to 40 minutes long, and with each passing minute, I'm stunned. I don't think any other film director can match intense, epic battle sequences as incredible as what Peter Jackson has pulled off here. Other strong sequences are Sam's fight with a creepy-looking CGI spider named Shelob and the climatic showdown on Mount Doom alongside Aragon's battle at the Black Gate. 

What succeeds more than these already excellent battle sequences is the story. As with the RT consensus, it's "emotionally powerful." The characters are developed at the highest level, to the point where we root for the good characters in the movie, especially Frodo, Sam, and Aragorn. Some have complained over the multiple endings explaining the fates of the characters, but as for me, I was still impressed. I wanted to find out what happened to these great characters, and they're endings were handled perfectly well, maybe even making some cry in the case of a certain number.

Helping make Return of the King the already incredible experience it is is the acting. I'm not going to write a lengthy paragraph about how great each actor/actress is here, I'll just they that each one involved did a truly fantastic job and creates that emotionally powerful finale that should not be missed. Standouts here include Elijah Wood, Sean Astin, Ian McKellen, Viggo Mortenson, Bernard Hill, Miranda Otto, John Noble as the mad steward, and especially, Andy Serkis as Gollum. What surprises me the most about this is that no actor didn't receive an Oscar nomination when the film literally won about every other award in the book, including Best Picture. I could picture Viggo and Serkis receiving Best Supporting Actor nominations at least. The Academy can be really stupid sometimes...

And last, Howard Shore's score for this excellent final chapter is Shore at his all-time best. Shore uses the great themes present in the first two that were already fantastic and scores a heavily, emotionally satisfying score that's one of the best scores I've heard in the past decade or so. I'm also impressed by the closing song by Annie Lennox, "Into the West", one of the most moving songs I've ever heard in my life. Music plays a huge part in handling this phenomenal final chapter, and Shore's music definitely doesn't disappoint here.  

The Lord of the Rings: The Return, simply put, is the greatest final chapter ever made in a film franchise, better than Back to the Future III, better than Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2, and better than The Dark Knight Rises. Peter Jackson proves he's definitely the filmmaking genius here, with some visually excellent battle sequences, an emotionally powerful story, and compelling acting and characters. Even with The Hobbit films (which are still great even if they're not up to LOTR standards), there's no doubt in my mind that Peter Jackson will be the modern George Lucas when it comes to wowing us at state-of-the-art visuals and excellent stories. I'm really stunned here!

I honestly have no clue why so many people love dungeons and dragons, and the Middle Ages.  They're so lame and corny that it makes Drake seem cool.  I mean seriously, these films suck.  Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the King is an adaptation of J.R.R Tolkien's book of the same name.  While I have tried countless of times to read it, I just couldn't get into it.  It seems rather bland.  So, nearly 50 years since the books release, King of the Bronies, Peter Jackson, hath claimeth the mantle to create the film.  I've tried watching these films countless of times, but I always fall asleep.  Not because they're boring.....Well, they are very tedious.  But mainly cause I start the film at 9pm and it goes well beyond my time limit.  I'm not doing this on purpose, but I just forget to watch it until it's pretty late.  So I watched it fully.  It was bad, very bad.

First off, I won't discount the special effects, costume, or set design.  The reason being is that.....well, it's amazing.  It feels like a true dungeon and dragons film.  Unfortunately, this film is weighed down by some hilarious dialogue.  "One does not simply walk into Morador" being probably the cheesiest of them all.  Seriously, at some point, you'll feel like you're watching a bunch of seriously handsome nerds role playing.  People say the adventure was the greatest thing about this film, but they're wrong.  If I were to watch people walking across a mountain or lake or grassland, I'd watch one of those Discovery channel "Meet the Buzamboo tribe of Africa" specials.  I'm watching a movie, and I'd prefer if there was more to it than walking and a small burst of fights.  

Seriously, this could have been one of the best movies ever made. That's right, I'm saying it is not. Even the casual movie fan (movie fan, not one of the mindless herd) has to admit that he/she can sense the fear in the producer's hearts behind every scene in this movie. They took a great risk in making an expensive trilogy like this, and they did not want to get the short end of the stick. The result is a compromise; a combination of good effects and good acting counterpointed with unnecessary cheeze-ball action and, well, bad acting. The result is a bizarre movie with brilliant scenes followed by terrible scenes.

Elijah Wood. I had trouble at first putting a description to his particular form of bad acting. I came up with the phrase, "blank acting", because he always has that one blank look on his face. You know the one, and the example that comes to mind is the look on his face in the scene where the ring "accidentally falls through the air and lands directly over his finger". A friend of mine found a review that had a better description than mine: "What he does is not acting, it is face-making, and anyone can do it".

Overall, it's a beautiful film to look at.  The sets, CGI, and some of the acting (particularly Sean Bean as the tragic knight) were pretty nice.  Unfortunately, there is a stupid script with some horrible acting (Elijah Wood as the Frodo)  It was a daring move.  You know, adapting a beloved book series (which I couldn't read), but I'm just not a dungeons and dragons type of guy.  I mean, I can understand some of the love it gets, but it's not my cup of tea.  It may be a technical beast, but it's also emotionally shallow and empty.

2.5/10

The best of the trilogy and one of the most all-around brilliant movies ever made.  Not only is it epic because it is the conclusion to a great adventure, but because the movie compromises nothing,  In it's final chapters it risks everything to be grand, to be memorable, to be better than the first two, and it succeeds in every area.  It has the narrative strength of the first movie and the grand battle scenes of the second.  While the running time is long, you hardly notice the time flashing by as the movie engulfs your imagination.  It's a great feeling enjoying the first hour of the movie and realizing you still have another two hours of brilliant entertainment left before it's time to say final goodbyes.  The best conclusion to any trilogy or series of movies ever.  Better than Star Wars VI, Harry Potter 7 part 2, and miles better than the Dark Knight Rises.  It deserved all 11 Academy Awards it won.  One of my favorite movies of all time.  It also contains one of my favorite scenes in any movie as Merry is singing to the would be king in the Great Hall as the "king's" son rides off to an almost certain death against the orcs.

The Return of the King is the definition of epic. The battle sequences are phenomenal and very well shot. Just when I thought the Lord of the Rings series couldn't be any more satisfying, this movie came. This movie does perfectly what some series cannot, wrap up all the plot points from the previous films, deliver fantastic action, fully develop all character arcs, and provide all the entertainment one could possibly have at the movies. It even packs an emotional punch, as Frodo reaches Mount Doom to complete his quest once and for all. Jackson's passion for filmmaking is truly felt throughout the whole 3 hour 21 minute movie. For such a long film, I was never bored and was 100% invested in every story and every battle that was occurring. It has a magnificent score, wonderful characters, beautiful emotional bonds, and some of the most breathtaking and phenomenal battles ever put to film. This is my favorite movie of all time for a reason, I can't thin of anything wrong with this unforgettable masterpiece. It will more than satisfy those wanting an epic blockbuster and critics looking for a perfectly made film.

From sweeping set-pieces to beautiful imagery, from astounding CGI to the epic harmonical tunes of composer, Howard Shore. Providing fans with the emotional last chapters of their heroes' stories - iced over with perhaps the most impressive battle sequences ever put to film - Peter Jackson does no more than deliver the epic masterpiece that was expected of him.  Fair enough, the continuous endings are a little annoying after a while.  But in my opinion, they were deftly handled and sealed the movie perfectly.  The idiots that complain about the ending sequences are probably the same idiots that complain about Harry Potter doing the direct opposite.  The movie is very long, but anything shorter would have been a crime.  Although just like the other movies, it isn't entirely without its flaws.  Again, Aragorn, Gimli and Legolas, just get a little too far-fetched in their warrior perfections.  I also think the whole story with Merry becoming a soldier was all but wasted, serving little importance to what the rest of the script projected, and so was basically an unnecessary add-on, just to remind us that he still existed.  Conversely, however, I really like the emphasis the film makes on Pippin and Galdalf's friendship, and although the drama-triangle between Frodo, Sam, and Gollum, does have its low points in forced, comedic distractions, their final plight with the giant spider and Sam's heroic return is incredibly satisfying.  Basically, there's too many good and bad points to list here, so I won't bother trying.  It basically comes down to whether you're a fan of the series.  If you are, then 'Return Of The King' is yet another fantastic movie, based on a fantastic book, and since these films never sacrificed character and spirit for sheer, ground-breaking spectacle, one can easily invest themselves into its grand-scale story of good triumphing over evil, and the enduring quality of friendship, so as to ignore its minor downfalls, and love it for the brilliance it really is.

The Lord of the Rings finishes on a high note, with an explosive finale that showcases the best of Peter Jackson and Middle Earth.

Return of the King sticks the landing, and then some. This is the greatest closing act of any trilogy ever made. Like the two films that came before it, every frame feels special, with countless details and work put into even the smallest moments- truly a labor of love. Return of the King delivers on the epic battles you would expect, and then exceeds expectations even further. The Rohirrim charge at Pelennor is one of the single greatest moments in any film, ever. This finale features the best visual moments of the trilogy (and that is saying something), the CGI, locations, sets, and models all blend seamlessly together. Somehow after 20 years this movie looks better than anything released today. What makes it so spectacular is that the massive, world shaking moments never for a moment cause the narrative to waiver. The attention to the characters that we've come to love is at the forefront of even the biggest spectacles. The last 40 minutes bring the emotions out like you wouldn't believe. Seeing beloved characters reunite and then finally part ways leaves audiences emotionally wrecked, regardless of how many times you've seen it. Return of the King will leave you exhausted and satisfied, and even after 4 hours (if watching extended) you still won't quite want it to end.

The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King is a monumental, epic, and emotionally moving final chapter to the spectacular trilogy that has given us some of the most memorable moments in film history.

This movie, being longer than its predecessors, has a LOT going on. There are wizards to visit, villagers to move home, cities to warn, armies to mobilize, paths to climb, monsters to avoid, battles to fight, wounded to heal, friends to save, and oh yeah, wasn't there something to do with a ring? Be prepared for a lot of intense plot to come right at you. It's full, but it's all full of good stuff. 

By this point, we've met all the important characters (although John Noble as Denethor is a character I love to hate). This allows for us to get right to the plot, and it moves swiftly, but not so fast as to ignore context or the emotional weight of the movie's events. 

After all the grand battles and desperate climbs up Mount Doom, the movie does give you time to relax and let go. It seems to end in several places, only to cut to voiceover narration, and yet another scene. I love hearing what happens, but don't tease us, Peter Jackson! That said, the ending is very sweet and emotional, bringing even the toughest football players to sniffles.

Trilogy Review:

The extended edition of this trilogy, came closer to the book than the theatrical version. The character development and alternate scenes of the battles made you feel like you were watching a completely different film. The visuals on this trilogy were fantastic that it made me a fan of New Zealand Landscapes, which by the way, occupies my desktop and mobile wallpapers.

Peter Jackson has done a phenomenal job at translating the books into the next trilogy that has been competing quite well with THE trilogies of all trilogies; Star Wars Episodes IV, V and VI. This is a film that will do you well to learn the in and outs of if you're a student of filmmaking.

While it doesn't have the bores of the first instalment or the annoying side-casting of key characters in the second, it manages to, like the previous films, come up with new things to dislike that make the ridiculously hard work that must have went into the series, seem like a bit of a waste in the end.

This one is essentially a 2-hour fight scene (each fight seems to merge into one big one) with half an hour of underdeveloped plot lines (ones that had actually been built up rather well until in here) and a half-hour long ridiculously cheesy concluding-thing (it's just too long to be called an ending). That leaves like 25 minutes of movie so let's just say it's Frodo staring and close-ups of that Elvish guy. 

The visuals are yet again stunning but after about 6 hours of them before this one even starts, the effect begins to wear off. It doesn't help that the majority of this one is CGI either- the realism fades the more it's used until it all just feels like a demo for a computer game- you don't even get to play it for yourself. The other films avoided that but this one is just animation overkill.

For me it's a disappointing conclusion to a trilogy that has such remarkable beauty throughout but also so many damaging flaws. Even though so many people must have put so much heart into it- it still feels heartless in comparison to the source material. Most action flicks are heartless but this one aims for more but sadly just doesn't make it.

An epic conclusion to one the greatest trilogy of all time.  The cinematography, soundtrack, acting, sets, costumes, and screenplay are all absolute top notch.  Beyond this, looking at the special edition production documentaries, it is absolutely incredible how much work and attention to detail went into the production of this trilogy.  From the WETA workshop models and minimodels exact down to the chips in worn stone to the thousands of concept artwork pieces, the staff did more than anyone could imagine to make Middle Earth come to life, and perhaps that is what makes the films so good--the trip feels real.

"The Return of the King" is unabashedly sentimental and chock full of spectacle, but it all works. I yearn for the smaller-scale action of "Fellowship," and the literal Spotlight of Sauron is kinda silly, but great performances (particularly from Viggo Mortensen and Sean Astin) keep things feeling grounded and honest amidst the CGI beasties and ghosts and armies and stuff. I'm deeply nostalgic with these flicks. Powerful and satisfying.

Para mi El Retorno del Rey es una obra maestra. Cuesta pensar que ha pasado una decada desde su estreno, y cuesta principalmente porque es una pelicula que a 10 años se ve totalmente vigente. Siempre es dificil traspasar un libro al cine, y las comparaciones son inevitables. Con esta triología, Jackson se convierte para mi en uno de esos casos en los cuales no puedo decidirme a señalar que es mejor, si el libro o las peliculas. Con sus notables diferencias, cada uno es capaz de atrapar a lectores y espectadores, haciendo olvidar las variaciones en la trama o los detalles perdidos. Es un cierre espectacular a las 2 peliculas anteriores. No por nada dicen que El Retorno del Rey fue el peor problema que pudo tener Geroge Lucas cuando quizo hacer la nueva trilogia de Star Wars, como alcanzar tan notable resultado? Como es logico, esta es la pelicula que se llevo el reconocimiento de todos los premios (12 oscar, por ejemplo), eso que no compitio en ninguna categoria de actuacion por motivos logicos. La musica de Howard Shore son verdaderas sinfonias en tiempos modernos No puede faltar. 100% recomendable.

Introduction
The Return of the King is the finale of The Lord of the Rings trilogy. Worldwide the movie made $1,119,929,521, becoming the 6th highest grossing film ever. It also became the 2nd movie in history to make more than 1 billion dollars. Out of all three movies, Return of the King was the highest grossing. The critical response was amazing! On rotten tomatoes it was rated a fresh 94%. The audience rating average is 8.6 out of 10. So overall it was a very high rated movie by critics and audiences alike. It has been called the number 1 movie in 2003. Today it is still one of the top rated movies ever! The only big criticism of the movie is the length, some people said it was way to long, and kinda drags at certain parts. Overall though the movie is highly acclaimed and many critics and audiences alike loved it!

Plot Summary-
Being the third and final film, the film hits the ground running. Aragorn, Legolas, Gimli, Theoden King and Gandalf arrive at Isengard. They find that the Ents, Merry and Pippin, have taken over and destroyed Isengard. All Gandalf needs to do is get the information he needs for Saurman the White, who is hiding in a tower at Isengard. After exchanging a few word with Saurman, his servant Wormtongue comes up behind his and stabs him. Saurman then falls off the tower and falls on a spike and dies. Pippin sees that Saruman dropped a fortune ball looking thing. He goes and picks it up and almost immediately Gandalf comes and takes it from him. That night, Pippin does a few things, that makes Gandalf take him to Minas Tirith. Then the king of Rohan decides that if Minas Tirith calls for help, they will answer. Aragorn, Gimli and Legolas decide to take the Paths of Death to attempt to get the help of a ghost army. Then, Merry rides to war with the Rohan army, only to be dropped of at Helms Deep. While all of this is happening Frodo, Gollum and Sam are slowly making their way to Mount Doom. There is a betrayal and one member of the group is left behind. The other two have a fatal encounter with a giant spider named Shelob. Will Frodo destroy the ring? Will Aragorn take his rightful place as king? What will happen to Aragorn, Gimli and Legolas on the paths of death? What happens with Merry and Pippin? Watch the movie and you will find out!!!


Awards won
In the 76th annual Academy Awards, Lord of the Rings, Return of the King was nominated for 11 oscars! In the end Return of the King won every award it was nominated for!!! It won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Original Score, Best Original Song, Best Sound Mixing, Best Art Direction, Best Makeup, Best Costume Design, Best Film Editing and Best Visual Effects. Overall the trilogy itself had won a total of 13 oscars!!! And I feel like they deserved each and everyone of them! The movie has amazing special effects, amazing music and amazing acting. The movie itself is just a amazing work of so many amazing people! They all worked their butts off to make sure the movie came together and came together wonderfully. So yes I do believe the film deserved the Oscars it won, I even believe that it should have won more.

Themes
Return of the King has many themes, but the main theme is that a little person could make a BIG difference. Frodo and Sam are these little people that lived in a perfect happy little place. Then Frodo is given the duty to go and take the Ring of Power to Mount Doom. Merry and Pippin manage to become soldiers and help fight Mordor's armies. These little people aka Hobbits manage to many things that older and bigger people couldn't do! Through out the movie they are underestimated, but they just keep doing bigger and bigger things. Sure they are not the smartest or the biggest, but all the Hobbits manage to do amazing things

Technical Elements
This movie is probably half special effects and awesome battle sequences, which makes the movie even better! Where do I start? Well there is a pretty epic battle sequence that takes place at Mina's Tirith. They animated 10,000s orcs to represent Mordor's armies. Then there is a incident that involves flying heads and rocks, so all that was CGI and animation. Also there is a incident that involves a giant spider named Shelob, so the fight was her was almost all CGI, but it looked pretty real. I could go on forever describing all the special effects, but I'll move on. The overall look of the film was really cool, it looked neat and real. I think the fact that almost all the landscape was real helped the movie look even better. The music like always was beautiful, it caught the tension and all the emotions of the story. Without the music the movie probably would have not been as good as it was. Return of the King would be almost nothing without the technical effects, but because of them the movie is the best it could ever be.

Overall opinion
I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS MOVIE!!! This movie will always be on the top of my list. I'm a HUGE Lord of the Rings fan and this movie made me very happy. It followed the book pretty well, except a few points, but I won't get into that. The movie is just the epic conclusion of a original and fantastic story. I feel like there is no way to make it better! I would recommend this book to any one who loves Lord of the Rings, for it doesn't disappoint. Also any one that wants a original and different story, because that is exactly what Return of the King is. Anyone that enjoys fantasy full of dragons, wizards and elves, I think would definitely enjoy this movie. Overall I think very highly of the movie and it will always have a special place on my heart. 

-MD, 8th Grade Student

The Lord Of The Rings: The Return Of The King (2003)

Rating: ? Stars or 86/100 (86%) *SPOILERS*

The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King is the epic, sleek, and long final installment of Peter Jackson's LOTR film trilogy. Since The Return of the King's blockbuster debut in theatres, way back in 2003. Jackson's collection has grown and swelled into one of the greatest trilogies ever created in the film industry. The only trilogies that may have Lord of the Rings beat are The Godfather, The Matrix Trilogy, The Dark Knight Trilogy, and the original Star Wars films (for sure). 

In the beginning, the film somewhat drags on... and on, and on, and on... The first 45 minutes to an hour is nothing but flashbacks, visions, and waking up in a cold sweat from bad nightmares. I understand that it is all used for setting up the final 2 hours of the film, but some casual fans may have nodded off in the beginning.

However, the film's action and awe sparking moments starts seemingly out of nowhere and last until the movie's final minute. Aragorn, with the company of his fellow side kicks Legolas and Gimli, enter a mountain to request the aid of a brigaide of dead warriors seeking redemption and following orders from the King of Gondor himself, Aragorn. Soon after, Smeagol convinces Frodo that Sam is after the ring, which is confusing because the most obvious thing in the entire movie is how in love Sam is with Frodo. Bromance x100. Anyways, shortly after, Smeagol tricks Frodo into entering a cave on the way to Mt. Doom in Mordor. Frodo soon realizes that a large spider inhabits the cave. After a struggle, Frodo escapes the cave and tosses Smeagol off a cliff in a skirmish. Continuing, the spider trails close behind and sticks Frodo with her poison gland. Then this giant ass spider wraps his ass up in a good country mile of spider web, only to flee due to Sam's return and heroics with his erection.. err-ehm, I mean sword. Then, the battle that the past three films has been leading to takes place for a solid hour, hour and a half, being led by Gandalf the White and at LEAST a quarter million horses. The battle is epic to say the least. 

By The Return Of The King, I am sick and tired of hearing and seeing Pippin and Charlie from LOST's little hobbit ass. 

In the end, Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King satisfies without reaching too far and trying to accommodate the expectations.

Peter Jackson's finale to the Lord of the Rings trilogy proves to be the most epic and entertaining. The film picks up right where Two Towers left off with Sauron planning his first attack on Middle-Earth to try and conquer it. Meanwhile, Frodo and Sam are being led by Gollum/Smeagol to Mordor in order to destroy the ring without realizing that Gollum has a secret plan to get it for himself. Like most finales to film series, most of the characters have already been developed and a majority of the film turns into a bunch of action sequences to create closure in the series. However, despite the action sequences, the opening is the dullest part of the film. Other than the interesting scenes with Gollum (including how he got the ring in the beginning of the film), nothing much really happens other than preparing for battle and it takes way too long. Nevertheless, once the action scenes actually started to happen, I completely forgot about the drab opening and was fixated all the way to the end. Once again, Gollum is the star of this film. The way Andy Serkis portrays him is just off the walls good. Also working for the film was the action sequences. There were moments that were exhilarating and so exciting that I had a huge grin on my face. I also dug the climax of the film which had to be the best part of the movie. Once all the action dies down, the story starts to slow down again. There were many scenes that they could've removed, but I didn't really mind because I was really enjoying the aftermath scenes. Overall, if you liked the first two Lord of the Rings films, you will not be disappointed with this magnificent conclusion to an astounding trilogy.

The return of the king is a nice ending to a beautiful trilogy, wining eleven Oscars including Best Picture and Best Director, this movie is just too good an ending and if you are watching this trilogy, just look forward to the ending where you get to see, the ring destroyed (in the most unbelievable twist, that is if you have not read the book) and Aragon rise to the throne that he was meant to be upon.
Here is what The Fellowship of the Ring movie was heading to, an ending that will remain the minds of movie watchers for years to come.

The movie has a massive number of visual effect shots that triple and double that of The Fellowship of the Ring and The Two Towers respectively, these shots can be seen clearly as the movie nears the end with the battles at Rohan which were quite filled with many CGI implementations and look forward to when Aragon goes searching for new recruits, there you will another set of visual effects

The film and the novel differ so much but that doesnâ(TM)t deter the film from its professionalism in the master art of storytelling, from the hand of Peter Jackson. The movie show cases an intense directorial work, which you just have to be impressed about. The actors were just charming but in this movie three people stole the show, Elijah Woods (Frodo Baggins), Sean Astin (Samwise Gamgee) and Viggo Mortensen (Aragon).

The movie tale continues from where Two Towers left up, Frodo and Sam are nearing Mordo and getting close to destroying the ring of power. The other members of the fellowship (which have united by the end of The Two Towers) went out to save Gondor from the hands of Sauronâ(TM)s army, the battle at Minas Tirith.

As all this is going on, Elrond (Hugo Weaving, Agent Smith from the Matrix and V from V for Vendetta in 2005) approaches Aragon and tells him, the only way he can win this fight to save Gondor is if he wills the sword Anduril and claim that, which he has been running from; claim his Kingship. 
Hence the name of the film/novel âThe Return of the Kingâ?

Making over a billion dollars from the box office, The Return of the King, sold more tickets than its previous two counterparts. Although The Fellowship of the Ring is considered by most to be the best of the three, this movie ranks second.

After you are done reading this, it is not complete yet till you go and get the DVD Extended version box set of The Lord of the Rings and make sure you get the novels also.

The Oscar wins for the movie at the 76th Academy Awards in 2004 were: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Original Score, Best Original Song, Best Visual Effects, Best Art Direction, Best Costume Design, Best Make-up, Best Sound Mixing and Best Film Editing.

"Here at last, on the shores of the sea... comes the end of our Fellowship."

The last film in the trilogy 'Return of the King' is almost as good as the film it preceded. An excellent and a somewhat emotionally draining experience. I don't think it could have been ended better.

Continuing directly from where the last one finished things continue to build. Like the first one there is an issue with length (not as much though) it could have benefited slightly with some time shaved off. But that's a very small issue, the different character stories all happening at the same time - it could've been too overbearing but there's breathing room and each character is making clear progress. There's also more back story to 'Gollum' and how he first came into contact with the ring. There's also a more of a psychological edge to the third film with a battle of wills carrying greater importance this time.

Unsurprisingly visually it's great again - some of the green screen stuff is a tad rough. The action is intense and frequent as well as 3 huge battles that open the scale of the world yet again. Acting is great again with 'Serkis' and 'Astin' being the stand out two carrying the film to a satisfying ending.

'Return of the King' concludes the trilogy is fantastic style there's a larger psychological edge this time around and yet again memorable battles and scenes. Thus ends one of the greatest movie trilogies of all time.

Although its majestic special effects are still impressive ten years after, this movie was overloaded with supporting characters and secondary storylines, making it difficult for the viewer to follow the complex story of the whole saga. The story, although powerful and thrilling, is sometimes repetitive and too long, but it is still a satisfying conclusion to the trilogy.

The final, Oscar-winning finale to Peter Jackson's "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy is just as powerful, if not more powerful, than it's predecessors.

As the various story arcs come to a conclusive, the film front loads all it's tense action, with Gollum's scheming, the battle with the Spider, the attack on Gondor and the battle of Mordor happening in reasonably quick succession, leading to Frodo finally managing to send the ring to the depths of Mount Doom.

The cast, including Elijah Wood, Sean Astin, Billy Boyd, Dominic Monaghan, Ian McKellen, Viggo Mortensen, Orlando Bloom, John Rhys-Davis, Andy Serkis, Bernard Hill, Karl Urban, Miranda Otto, Hugo Weaving, Liv Tyler and David Wenham return once again with a brilliant performance from everyone, and John Noble joins the cast well as the mad and cold Steward Denethor II. Late appearances by Cate Blanchette and Ian Holm as Lady Galadriel and Bilbo Baggins respectively were also welcome.

This is very much a film that knows how to tug on the heartstrings. The friendship shown by Astin's Samwise Gamgee towards Wood's struggling Frodo Baggins, particularly after the betrayal by Gollum, kept the audiences emotions high for the finale, when the surviving Fellowship - Merry, Pippin, Aragorn, Legolas, Gimli and Gandalf - storm the black gate of Mordor ahead of the rest of the army, showing the strength of friendship.

That makes it all the more heartbreaking when the Fellowship splits, not through disaster, but by the same method that any friendship group splits - through time.

As reunions and farewells come and go alarmingly rapidly towards the end, the emotion is kept high right until the end.

Another scene which to me added to the emotion was the appearance of the Eagles to deter the Nazgul from their pursuit of Frodo and the Ring. It holds to me the same sort of emotion that the appearance of the Hammerhead Rhinocerous in James Cameron's Avatar has in the final battle - Nature fighting back. I've always been partial to that.

I could go on forever, but the basic gist is that this is a fantastic film. And a satisfying conclusion to an amazing trilogy.

I'm going to come right out and say it, The Return of the King is the best conclusion to a trilogy I have ever seen. The movie is literally overflowing with content. Full of equal amounts of action and drama, Peter Jackson absolutely nails it! He is somehow able to handle dozens of characters and multiple plot-lines. And unlike the second movie, he balances everything perfectly.

The journey is taking its toll on Frodo and Sam. Even if they rid themselves of the One Ring, and make it back to the Shire, they will never be the same. With no clear way to get into Mordor, Gollum suggests they use a secret tunnel he knows of. He is actually tricking them; in this tunnel is Shelob, a giant spider. Gollum plans let Shelob kill Frodo and then take back his "Precious". Meanwhile, a crucial battle for Middle Earth is about to be waged. But Aragorn, Gimli, and Legolas need help. They venture into the Paths of the Dead to recruit an army. Sauron's army lays siege on man's last hope, Minas Tirith. Frodo escapes Shelob and presses on towards the fires of Mount Doom.

I cannot praise the story, direction, and acting in this movie enough. Starting with the acting. Elijah Wood, Viggo Mortensen, Sean Astin, Andy Serkis, and Ian McKellen all give phenomenal performances. All of these actors are able to bring their characters story arcs to a satisfying end. Of course they are helped out by some wonderful writing, but the actor's performances cannot be taken for granted. The supporting cast members also hit all the emotional marks. Of special note are Orlando Bloom, Miranda Otto, Bernard Hill, and Liv Tyler.

But none of this would have been possible without the steady hand of Peter Jackson. How he is able to hold it all together and give us an Oscar winning movie us almost inconceivable. It's very common for the third movie in a franchise to be the worst. And almost always, if it had two great movies coming before it, the third movie will disappoint. But I honestly can't think of anything disappointing about this movie. The level of excellence that Jackson was able to maintain throughout this trilogy is staggering.

The movie is 200 minutes long. But somehow there is always something happening. There are never any dry moments. The action is intense and frequent. Jackson gives us the scale required for this to be a satisfying conclusion, but still keeps the action character driven.

Everything in this movie is executed to perfection. And The Return of the King has 11 Oscar wins to prove it. There is a bit of controversy about the ending. Did Peter Jackson really need half an hour after the action ends to tie up the loose ends? I'd say absolutely. With such a long ending, the audience doesn't feel like it's been shorted in any way. And Jackson pulls it all off flawlessly. The entire movie is so emotionally powerful. When I saw this movie for the first time about 2 years ago, I cried at the end. That was the first time I had cried during a movie in a very long time, and I haven't since then. That's how powerful the ending was for me. This movie and the entire trilogy hold a special place in my heart. Flawless!

"My friends, you bow to no one." 10/10

The Return of the King takes everything great about the first two films, amplifies it and steps it up. This final installment in the trilogy gives you both the most exciting battle and also the most moving conclusion you'll ever see.

The journey of Frodo and Company comes to an end, will they destroy the ring?  The Lord Of The Rings: The Return Of The King is an excellent finale to the series.  It's based off the third book from Tolkien and is my personal favorite.  It's filled with more stunning visuals and great effects.  There's a good amount of action as well including a nice final battle scene.  The script is smart and wraps up all the different storylines nicely.  I loved the opening scene which gives us a light on Gollum's backstory.  I thought the bromances between Frodoa and Sam and merry and Pippin are a bit passionate, but what happens in the shire, stays in the shire.  When I first saw the film in theatres I had to drain my dragon badly and kept getting tricked by the ending scenes.  These final scenes are glorious and ends the three film epic in a grand fashion.  Peter Jackson did a great job all around through the trilogy as Director.  The top notch cast reprises their roles including Elijah Wood, Ian McKellan, Viggo Mortensen, Liv Tyler, Sean Astin, Orlando Bloom and of course Andy Serkis as Gollum, my favorite character.  This time around, the film won eleven Oscars including Best Picture.  While it's a looong journey, The Lord Of The Rings: Return Of The King is one of the best third parts to one of the greatest trilogies in film.

I am too lazy to write a review for each LoTR movies so let me give an overall review in this last part that also happened to be my favorite. LoTR is all I expected from a fantasy film: a detailed story, memorable characters, breathtaking sets and heart-gripping actions. Not to mention the rush of feels and emotions I rarely experienced when watching a fantasy film. LoTR is Peter Jackson's magnum opus that I doubt will ever be dethroned, and I am sure when I say that watching this trilogy is the most satisfying experience I've ever had in a cinema.

No!  Gandalf don't go!  T^T  We love you!  ...There's nothing that's awesome about this movie that isn't awesome about the book -- aside from almost perfect casting and stunning visuals, and near-perfect execution all the way down to voices and oliphants! As with the Two Towers, Frodo is the main setback, being emo and whiny about having volunteered and leaving all his heroic qualities that made him man up in the first place back in the books and in the Fellowship of the Ring. Aragorn seems to have left some of his own self-confidence back in the pages of Tolkien but makes up for it in an otherwise great representation and command of the screen and delivers a riveting speech - I was ready to go die fighting Mordor to buy time for furry-footed halflings. Gandalf is the shit as always - it's not his fault that we don't understand why he didn't just call in the eagles to *get* the hobbits there, or why he didn't use his crazy awesome powers sooner to help in the fight - that's Tolkien's fault.  Gimli and Legolas are on-point as always and ready at just the right times with some comic relief.  Elrond still looks perma-angry, and who can blame him when some mortal's after his daughter, Mr. Anderson? I'm disappointed that more time wasn't spent on character development and less time on a seemingly endless run from point to point so we can fight over the ring some more like has dominated the flow of the last 2 movies - but action junkies must be catered to I suppose. Other than that and Frodo's whininess this movie is epic - like the book it's based on. Not perfect, but so close to perfect that you might not notice.

It is really rare when a trilogy has a third movie that works. In almost every great trilogy, the third film is often the weakest! The Godfather trilogy, the original Star Wars trilogy, the Spider-Man trilogy etc. I kept my expectations low going into this movie because the third film of every trilogy usually disappoints me. After I walked out of this movie I could only think one thing. This is not only the best LOTOR film, but also one of the greatest masterpieces ever put on film! The scale is larger than the other two LOTOR films, the battles were just as large, long and epic, and every character is done justice in the script and with the performances of the amazing cast. Notable characters that I enjoyed watching were Andy Serkins as Gollum, and Elijah Woods as Frodo. Every scene with these two characters were extremely well done! Gollum was already suspenseful  as a character, but Frodo really shines! The burden of carrying the ring really changes Frodo from the Hobbit we met in Fellowship. He has grown as a character and I really love how Elijah Woods portrayed him! Once again this film is an ensemble cast, and every character has their own moment to shine. There is a reason why this film won eleven oscars, and that is because it is one of the finest films of this era! I went into the theatres and sat through 4 hours! Yes this film is almost 4 hours long but you know what. I wished it were even longer than that! I am really going to miss the many adventures and battles that this trilogy has to offer, and I hope that everyone will enjoy this film as much as I did! Peter Jackson has created one of the greatest movie trilogies of all time! Thank you Peter Jackson, and all the cast and crew that were involved in this trilogy! You have created something truly special!

It's okay, even if it is the longest in the trilogy, but I still believe that the Oscars it got were really rewards for the trilogy as a whole.  I think it'd be a safe guess to say that the Academy probably felt that, given each of the three movies came out a year or less apart, it would probably be a bit unfairly premature to heap the customary awards on either of the previous films until the whole trilogy was completed, also because the trilogy really represents one story in three parts rather than three separate stories.  As for the film itself, I didn't find it as entertaining or emotionally satisfying as the previous two, between which I really don't have a favorite because I think both Fellowship of the Ring and Two Towers delivered about on-par with one another given that they had different things to bring to the saga.  The problem with this third entry is really in the adaptation because, even with its length, there is a lot of relevant story that had to be left out (or so I've heard) so no matter how long they draw it out, the ending ultimately feels a little abrupt.  Still, like its predecessors, it's a monumental achievement that, put with its predecessors, is worthy of the Tolkien name.

A spectacular conclusion to an excellent film trilogy, in The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King we see the characters develop to their full potential. We see the  largely spectacular special effects and beautiful art direction and cinematography that we witnessed in the first two and all the epic battles and showdowns we have enjoyed and hoped for.

While he stands out for me, all the other acting is almost equally as powerful and the character development is outstanding. The screenplay is clever and original and there is no reason why i would dislike this film in the slightest. Truly, The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King is the most powerful of the trilogy.

The Return of the King or The Return of of a Classic?
The answer is yes for both questions, having recently seen the extended version of the film after almost 10 years the film still surprisingly holds up. Now with Lord of the Rings I like to view it as a Epic split into 3 parts. So if you haven't seen the previous two don't bother till you do. In this film we get the final stretch of our heroes journey. I can explain more but doing so will give away some the films amazing moments. This film brings everything home to an entirely satisfying conclusion. It's epic, intersting, funny, and mostly sad. The last hour will have you choking up. Peter Jackson masterfully keeps the tension throughout to film down to the last minute the conflict is resolved. The dialougue amazing. The music essential and entirely in sync with the film. Most of all it the story of friends, love, amd never giving up that really brings everything to life. 4 hrs is a little long in the tooth but you won't notice it. The great thing is these extended cuts really make everything much more better. Everyone does really well but special mention to Sean Astin who brings the film full circle.  This one of the biggest epics, best finale, and ultimatley best trilogy of all time. You would be wise to watch them. Even if you hate them and you'll thank me afterwards. Although I have seen all of the Lord of the Rings films before, I had never read the books, and so recently I decided to read them. I then thought it might be fun to watch each film as I complete each part of the story. And so, having finished â~The Return of the Kingâ(TM) we come to the third and last of Peter Jacksonâ(TM)s films. For the record I have to say that I watched the extended version, available on DVD and Blu Ray.

NOTE: There may be spoilers in here; if you havenâ(TM)t seen the â~Fellowship of the Ringâ(TM) and â~The Two Towersâ(TM) please skip this paragraph.

We begin with some back-story on how Smeagol came across the ring; how it corrupted him and turned him into Gollum. Sam and Frodo are still on their way to destroy the ring and Gollum is still steering them along his chosen route into Mordor. A route that may work to his advantage. Meanwhile the rest of the fellowship is reunited briefly at Isengard before being split again when they ride to Rohan. They hear that Sauronâ(TM)s forces are on the march and they intend to attack Minas Tirith, a city of Gondor. Gandalf takes Pippin directly there after he steals a look at Sarumanâ(TM)s â~seeing stoneâ(TM) which is linked directly to Sauron. Gathering their forces, King Theodin and Aragorn set off towards Minas Tirith, only for Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli to leave them and take another path there. Aragorn has had word that he must fulfil a pact made by his ancestor if they are to succeed at Minas Tirith. With the city under siege, all seems lost as Sam and Frodo are split asunder by the cunning wiles of Gollum. I think thatâ(TM)s enough to whet the appetiteâ¦ for now.

Yet another epic film with tremendous scope; Peter Jackson and the many others that worked on this really did an excellent job! Yet again, the original music by Howard Shore is tremendous another great score with some really great themes, following on from the previous two films with great aplomb. As far as performances go, well everybody did a great job but those that stood out (for me) were; Elijah Wood as Frodo, Ian McKellen as Gandalf, Sean Astin as Samwise â~Samâ(TM) Gamgee, Viggo Mortensen as Aragorn and Bernard Hill as Theodin (King of Rohan). Also worthy of note were; John Noble as Denethor, Billy Boyd as Pippin, Dominic Monaghan as Merry, Orlando Bloom as Legolas, John Rhys-Davies as Gimli/Voice of Treebeard (briefly), Liv Tyler as Arwen, Miranda Otto as Eowyn, David Wenham as Faramir,  Christopher Lee as Saruman, Karl Urban as Eomer and not forgetting Andy Serkis as Gollum/Smeagol.

The book could very easily have been made into two films; there is such a lot that happens and so many twists in the plot that it might have benefitted if that were the case. But weâ(TM)re not here to speculate I guess; although it does depart from the book in many respects, I did find that most of the important bases were covered. A film which has some tremendous scenes of epic battles but also some very tender and thought-provoking moments as well. For me the most powerful scene was where Denethor has sent his son, Faramir, to his doom and is eating a meal while Pippin sings a haunting ballad. The intercutting of the images of battle with Denethor and Pippin safe in Minas Tirith and the haunting melody over the top makes for a scene that has stayed with me since I first saw it back in 2003. I did find it did tend to drag a bit towards the end, but other than that a very fine film that is a fitting end to a great trilogy.

SteelMonsterâ(TM)s verdict: HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

The first time I saw this movie, I was turning 11, and I saw it for my birthday.  It was the first Lord of the Rings I saw in theaters.  When the movie I ended, I wanted to cry because LOTR was over.  And at 11 years old, I couldn't exactly realize how good of a note the trilogy ended on.

Throughout the years, I've come to the conclusion:  'The Return of the King' is my favorite movie of all time.  Peter Jackson's finale to JRR Tolkien's famous books is the best ending I've ever witnessed to a series.  This movie hits everything on the point in all aspects.

The action is amazing in this movie.  From the Battle of Pelennor Fields to the final stand against Sauron, the action is breathtaking.  You can even include all of Sam's inspiring fight scenes and also Osgiliath.  There is a huge amount of action, but this action does not define this movie.  What does define this movie is the emotional acting.

Amongst all of the praise and all of the awards this film garnered, the performance that stands out the most in this film is Sean Astin as Samwise Gamgee.  When people ask me who my favorite character is in LOTR?  I always answer Sam.  Why?  Because Sean Astin gives the most inspiring, emotional, and heartbreaking performance of the entire trilogy.  As the sidekick best friend of Frodo, Sam is the yin to Frodo's yang.  He is the sanity to Frodo's INsanity.  And he made me cry... multiple times.  As did Frodo.  Their chemistry and struggles are what make LOTR so special.  Their final struggle to the top of Mount Doom is what defines 'Return of the King'.  Their final act deserves a standing ovation.  

Lastly, Howard Shore's score is amazing.  Every piece during every scene truly puts out the emotion that is within the film.  The combination of all three movie scores is one of my favorites of all time.

This will ALWAYS be my favorite film of all time.  Always.  Because it is one of the few which hits every emotion in me and breaks my heart the second the screen goes black.  I don't care what anyone else says, because hell, in my opinion, this could possibly be one of the top five films of ALL TIME.
